stream_context.summary: Kaze shows a major performance gain achieved since the last stream (notably by changing how coins are rendered), then pivots into planning and prototyping Course 11’s abandoned power plant/factory. He outlines a full room-by-room platforming progression (new weight-linked platforms, treadmills, collapsing grates, slide hazards), discusses lighting/visual goals, and shares production constraints (full-time job, move/house, neck pain).
stream_context.significance_reason: The stream contains a rare late-stage performance breakthrough (~10–15%), introduces/commits to a new core platform mechanic for Course 11 (weight-linked paired platforms), and lays out the complete intended room progression for the power plant level—material that strongly anchors interviewable design intent.

findings.summary: Since the previous stream, the team achieved an estimated 10–15% performance improvement—something Kaze calls unusually large at this stage of development.
findings.quote: We found like a 10–15% performance improvement. At this stage, that is crazy.

findings.summary: The performance gain came largely from changing coins from camera-facing billboards to screen-space rectangles/sprites, reducing rendering cost (CMD time drops from ~23.6 to ~22.0 in the showcased area).
findings.quote: Instead of having them be billboards, they are now rectangles in screen space… Every coin here is a sprite.

findings.summary: Kaze frames F3DEX3 as a future potential performance milestone, implying current optimization is meaningful but not the final ceiling.
He demonstrates a new star model/visual presentation and prefers it over vanilla SM64’s transparent star look.
findings.quote: I think this is a lot nicer than the transparent star in vanilla Mario 64.

findings.summary: Course 11’s next major task is the abandoned power plant/factory. Kaze says he already has the level planned as five sections, with at least two rooms sketched, and a defined “vibe” target.

He enumerates Course 11’s core platform set for the power plant: treadmills, dangling platforms (initially), and collapsing grates—then commits to replacing/repurposing the dangling concept into a new weight-linked platform pair mechanic.

A key design decision: instead of swinging platforms (which the game already has many of), Course 11 will feature paired “scale/weight platforms,” where standing on one lowers it and raises the other—explicitly to add a new platforming mechanic to the game’s vocabulary.
findings.quote: That would be a really cool platforming mechanic. I think we’re going with that idea.

findings.summary: Kaze outlines an explicit teaching progression: Room 1 sets mood + introduces weight platforms with low penalty for failure; Room 2 introduces treadmills with a safety net; then more weight-platform puzzle usage; then a timed slide with electric hazards; then collapsing grates; final room combines all mechanics to reach the star.
Visual/atmosphere goals for the power plant include potentially using fog and vertex lighting, with the idea that electricity elements in the environment provide the primary light sources.

Because Course 11 is indoors and segmented into separate rooms, Kaze believes it can tolerate higher polygon counts than outdoor areas via culling; he estimates the factory could potentially get away with ~30k–40k polys (while noting the current model is ~3k).

Kaze describes a paid arrangement with “Mata” to reorganize/upgrade the factory visuals; Mata asked for a commission due to needing money, but is now months overdue (quoted as ~4 months late on something originally claimed to take ~2 weeks), lowering Kaze’s confidence in the deliverable.

He introduces a new RTYI codebase approach for defining variables/memory layout intended to make RAM collisions easier to detect and avoid, implying ongoing infrastructure work to keep the project scalable.
Kaze expresses enthusiasm about having a tick function instead of a classic behavior loop, suggesting modernization of the gameplay-object update architecture in RTYI.

He prototypes the weight-platform physics, iterating on shared-velocity/constraint logic (e.g., velocities summing to zero, friction tweaks, return-to-neutral behavior), and acknowledges “hacking” physics to get a controllable, fun result (e.g., delayed acceleration and ground-pound advantage).
findings.quote: Sometimes you do need to hack the physics just a little bit to make everything work.

findings.summary: Difficulty target is roughly “vanilla Mario 64,” but Kaze notes RTYI’s controls work better, so challenges may look harder than they feel in practice.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposes repurposing the dangling/swinging platform concept into a new mechanic: paired weight platforms where one rises when the other is weighed down; Kaze adopts this as a unique platform type the game lacks.
On the black/oil boss, Biobak suggests routing the soap target to the outside grills/cages; Kaze agrees and notes it as a planned change.

zeina.summary: Kaze jokes that Zeina has “banished” him to a basement setup after their move, offering a glimpse into the home/work boundary during development (and his new physical workspace: CRT, multiple monitors, squat rack, Yoshi cabinet).
zeina.quote: Zeina has banished me here. She said I'm not allowed to come up unless it's to grab food.

findings.summary: Kaze commissioned Mata to reorganize/upgrade the factory visuals, but reports prolonged delays and subpar early progress, creating risk around Course 11’s visual schedule and forcing Kaze to plan around an uncertain external dependency.
findings.quote: He is four months overtime on something that he said would take him two weeks.

findings.summary: Kaze previews upcoming integration of Yoshi Milkman’s custom sound set for Mario 64, aiming for added immersion (e.g., different footstep/impact sounds on metal grates vs. other surfaces).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: We found like a 10–15% performance improvement. At this stage, that is crazy.
memorable_quotes.context: A rare, late-stage optimization jump that reframes what the team thinks is still possible on N64-era constraints.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Guys, this releases when it gets done. Like, literally just leave me alone.
memorable_quotes.context: A blunt boundary-setting moment about timelines, reflecting the strain of balancing a full-time job with a long-running passion project.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Sometimes my YouTube chat actually just fucking hurts me.
memorable_quotes.context: A candid frustration beat that could support a broader documentary theme about creator pressure, audience expectations, and emotional toll.

key_stories.title: Late-stage FPS breakthrough by redesigning coin rendering
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals a significant performance win achieved between streams—an unusually large gain at this point in development. The fix comes from reframing coins as screen-space sprites rather than billboards, unlocking higher FPS stability across previously heavy areas.
key_stories.challenge: Performance headroom was tight, and big gains were assumed unlikely until deeper pipeline upgrades like F3DEX3.
key_stories.process: Kaze changes coin rendering to screen-space rectangles/sprites and validates impact with and without the debugger, tracking CMD time reductions and FPS improvements in known-stress areas.
key_stories.outcome: He reports ~10–15% improvement, sees areas jump to near-consistent 60 FPS, and implies this may be the last optimization of that magnitude before F3DEX3.
key_stories.key_quote: Instead of having them be billboards, they are now rectangles in screen space… Every coin here is a sprite.

key_stories.title: Course 11 power plant design locked around a new “weight platform” mechanic
key_stories.summary: While initially considering dangling/swinging platforms, Kaze realizes the project already has many swinging elements and pivots to a new, more distinctive mechanic suggested by Biobak. He then outlines a structured, teach-then-combine level flow across multiple rooms built to introduce and stress-test three platform types plus hazards.
key_stories.challenge: Course 11 needed a signature indoor platforming identity, plus a clean onboarding sequence that avoids punishing early failures while still allowing a hectic final challenge.
key_stories.process: Kaze prototypes paired-platform physics (shared velocity constraints, friction tweaks, neutral return behavior) and drafts a room-by-room “curriculum” introducing weight platforms → treadmills → puzzle usage → slide hazards → collapsing grates → final combined room.
key_stories.outcome: He commits to the weight-platform mechanic, places early layout scaffolding (including star placement), and identifies additional atmosphere goals (fog/vertex lights, electricity as diegetic lighting).
key_stories.key_quote: That would be a really cool platforming mechanic. I think we’re going with that idea.

key_stories.title: External art dependency risk: the delayed factory visual rework
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains he paid Mata for a factory reorganization/visual upgrade but is now dealing with repeated delays and low confidence in delivery. This shapes how the team schedules and how much polish they can safely plan around for Course 11’s visuals.
key_stories.challenge: A commissioned visual rework has slipped far beyond its promised timeline, creating uncertainty for a key level’s look and potentially forcing fallback plans.
key_stories.process: Kaze references an early interim version that looked poor, describes Mata promising to “try harder,” and notes he will ask/check status; meanwhile, Kaze continues designing/prototyping gameplay and assumes indoor culling can support higher-poly visuals if/when they arrive.
key_stories.outcome: Confidence is low, but Kaze frames it as manageable because he anticipated risk; the level can proceed mechanically while art catches up (or doesn’t).
key_stories.key_quote: So I wouldn't say he's reworking the factory. I would say he is saying he's reworking the factory.

open_questions.topic: The coin rendering change and its broader performance strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze attributes a major FPS gain to rendering coins as screen-space sprites instead of billboards and hints future wins may depend on F3DEX3.
questions: When did you realize coins were a major performance lever—was it profiling data, intuition, or a specific worst-case scene?
What tradeoffs did you consider (visual fidelity, edge cases, animation/spin behavior) before committing to screen-space sprites?
How does this optimization change your remaining performance roadmap—does it delay or reduce the urgency of F3DEX3?

open_questions.topic: Course 11’s “platforming curriculum” and intended player experience
open_questions.context: Kaze gives a detailed room-by-room plan for teaching weight platforms, treadmills, slide hazards, and collapsing grates, culminating in a combined final room.
questions: What playtesting signals will tell you the introductory room is forgiving enough without making the mechanic feel trivial?
What’s the intended emotional arc of the factory—tension/horror, humor, industrial grit—and how should that evolve across the rooms?
How do you decide when a mechanic deserves its own teaching room versus being introduced in the middle of a challenge?

open_questions.topic: Design intent behind the new weight-platform physics (and “hacking” feel)
open_questions.context: Kaze iterates on shared-velocity math, friction, neutral return, and timing delays so the mechanic feels controllable and allows skill expression (e.g., ground-pound advantage).
questions: What does a 'correct' feel for the weight platforms look like in your mind—snappy, heavy, floaty, or somewhere in between?
Which player behaviors are you trying to enable (timing tech, height boosting, recovery options), and which are you trying to prevent (cheap skips, stalling)?
Can you describe a moment where the mathematically 'accurate' version felt worse than a hacked version—and how you chose fun over purity?

open_questions.topic: Managing external contributors and schedule risk (Mata’s factory rework)
open_questions.context: Kaze paid Mata for a factory visual rework that is months overdue, affecting confidence and planning for Course 11’s presentation.
questions: What did you originally commission Mata to do—pure reorganization, a new style pass, optimization, or all of the above?
At what point do you decide to wait longer versus taking the asset back in-house or finding a different approach?
How do you structure commissions now (milestones, check-ins, partial deliveries) after experiences like this?
